node.title: Second derivatives of FIRST LAGRANGE
node.bodyText:
Hi, I want to be able to compute second derivatives of a variable in a postprocessor. This is an energy with a corresponding Kernel. For the Kernel we got around this by integrating by parts and putting one of the spatial derivatives on the test function. However, for accurate analysis of the energy we need the second derivatives of our variables.
I am aware that second derivatives of FIRST LAGRANGE just return 0.0 because they are not stored but is there an easy way to track them?
edit: apologies if this was already asked in here, I tried search and couldn't find anything
The issue is that piecewise multilinear basis has zero second derivative. You'd want to project that variable onto a second order basis.

Is the procedure to let an AuxVariable be SECOND MONOMIAL and then use an AuxKernel to computeValue to store the value of the FIRST LAGRANGE
If so, I suppose that worked but I find the derivatives to be much much smaller than I expected.

Right, this won't work. By projecting something of first order onto a second order basis, you are essentially "adding information", and that additional information comes from nowhere. Think about the case where you want to make a line with constant slope (first order) become second order by adding an additional dof, that dof can be anywhere. For most conservative projections, you'll end up recovering the exact same straight line, hence the second derivative is very small.
Depending on your physics, you need to first figure out where that "additional information" may come from. Then there will be different ways of doing the projection. It's probably no longer appropriate calling it a projection, as projection typically loses information...

You would need the variables that are used to compute the energy, likely the nonlinear variables, to be second order. Then you may compute a second order derivative.
Otherwise you could build a stencil with more than one element to compute the second derivative. It's what we do in finite volume. It might not be super easy with the native coupleable (coupledValue etc) interface

@mangerij You can try something like this:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 20
  second_order = true
[]

[Variables]
  [u]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [v]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    [AuxKernel]
      type = NodalPatchRecoveryAux
      nodal_patch_recovery_uo = patch
      execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
    []
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [react]
    type = Reaction
    variable = u
  []
  [source]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = u
    function = 'sin(100*x)'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [u]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = u
    args = u
    function = u
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [patch]
    type = NodalPatchRecoveryMaterialProperty
    patch_polynomial_order = SECOND
    property = u
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 1
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]
This reconstructs a second order variable using a first order variable using the Zienkiewicz-Zhu patch recovery algorithm
The output looks like this:

I am also trying to do the same. Let's say I want to calculate the volume integral of d2u/dx2+d2u/dy2. Is it the right way to call it in the postprocessor kernel (indexing should be (0,0) and (1,1))?
return _mu * (_u[_qp]) * (_second_u[_qp](0,0) + _second_u[_qp](1,1)  );
Right now I am using a first order element for u. I might be able to use the second order element for my variable. If I do this, can the post processor return the integral correctly? It would be great if I can correctly integrate the second order derivative.
Thanks.

If first order lagrange that will just be 0
are you using coupledSecond ? From the coupleable interface
integration by parts to reduce the order of the derivative is what we usually do

For me, I should do the volume integration.
How about creating a multiapp and use the LaplacianSplit? (I assume it gives d2u/dx2+d2u/dy2)
Thanks.

I m not sure what you mean by that
Integration by parts is still a volume integration, just of a different term. And there's an additional boundary integral. But the reduction in order is worth it

node.title: Kernel produces "...was never added to this object's InputParameters"

node.bodyText: Ah great that fixed it,  thx!

node.title: Failed to run update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh on SAWTOOTH

node.bodyText:
Hello
what does which make return ? seems you dont have a cmake module loaded.
the configure.log file it made will have more information

I get the same error... investigating...
/tmp/jason_stuff/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.strumpack/src/sparse/fronts/FrontalMatrixLossy.cpp:31:10: fatal error: zfparray2.h: No such file or directory
 #include "zfparray2.h"
          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~

We might be missing a new library requirement with latest PETSc?
ZFP should be 0.5.5 - mamba by default provides 1.0.0 now. This was fixed up in the conda packages, but I guess this package is updated at a slower pace?
We don't update the Mamba packages on Sawtooth/Lemhi nearly as quick. Its manual. Pretty sure all I need to do, is install it.

Hmm, no its there:
zfp                       1.0.0                h27087fc_3    conda-forge

Here is the output for "module list and which make":
[wangc@sawtooth1 ~]$ module load use.moose moose-dev
[wangc@sawtooth1 ~]$ module list
Currently Loaded Modules:

use.moose                  4) patchelf/0.9-8.5.0          7) moose-dev/mvapich2-2.3.5
gcc/8.4.0-gcc-4.8.5-jacd   5) git/2.25.0-gcc-9.2.0-v4mv
mvapich2/2.3.5-gcc-8.4.0   6) mambaforge3

[wangc@sawtooth1 ~]$ which make
/usr/bin/make
Okay, it looks like we need to downgrade this package version... one minute... Done. Try to build now!

Well... it still fails for me with a new error:
/usr/bin/ld: warning: libzfp.so.0, needed by /tmp/jason_stuff/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libstrumpack.so, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)

I think our moose-dev environment on Sawtooth needs a re-haul. I really get nervous about that. Could mean previous versions of HPC binaries failing (there is only one Mamba environment).
@milljm Thanks for helping me on this. Do you have any solution for this issue?

I have found quite a few issues with our Conda implementation on Sawtooth (and Lemhi). Right now, I am able to build PETSc only if I drop the use of Conda all together.
If you're in a pinch and need a working build, this seems to work:
module purge
module load mvapich2/2.3.5-gcc-8.4.0 cmake/3.22.3-gcc-8.4.0-hrid python/3.8.6-gcc-9.3.0-5tcw
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
I haven't tried building libMesh afterwards, so this may not work for you... I am still trying to figure out how to implement Conda. We still need this for all the dependencies involved when building Documentation.
Edit:
Try using the up-to-date mvapich module instead of what I posted:
mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-8.4.0
I really appreciate for that. Please let me know if you make it work.

@milljm I have tried to rebuild moose on Lemhi, but I got the following error message:
module load use.moose moose-dev
(base) [wangc@lemhi1 bison]$ module list

Currently Loaded Modules:
  1) flex/2.6.4-gcc-11.2.0-wvjp    4) mvapich2/2.3.7-1                     7) use.moose
  2) bison/3.7.6-gcc-11.2.0-aysl   5) cmake/3.21.3-gcc-9.4.0-d22d          8) mamba3
  3) gcc/9.4.0-gcc-8.4.1-57pg      6) patchelf/0.13-oneapi-2021.4.0-uxhq   9) moose-dev/2023-10-05

run the following without error:

cd ~/cluster_name/projects/moose/scripts
export MOOSE_JOBS=6 METHODS=opt
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
./update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh

cd test
make -j 6

Then got the following error message:

Linking Library /home/wangc/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.la...
/usr/bin/grep: /apps/local/mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-8.4.0/lib/libmpicxx.la: No such file or directory
/usr/bin/sed: can't read /apps/local/mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-8.4.0/lib/libmpicxx.la: No such file or directory
libtool:   error: '/apps/local/mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-8.4.0/lib/libmpicxx.la' is not a valid libtool archive
make: *** [/home/wangc/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:394: /home/wangc/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.la] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

@milljm Do you have any suggest how to fix this issue?

I think you have a stale build:
$ ls /apps/local/mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-8.4.0/lib/libmpicxx.la:
ls: cannot access '/apps/local/mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-8.4.0/lib/libmpicxx.la:': No such file or directory

That directory does not (if ever) exists. Can you try a clean build?
Thanks, it works. @milljm

node.title: Using libtorch in MOOSE

node.bodyText:
This is because Tensor is defined in two headers that end up being included, and not properly namespaced to deconflict.
@grmnptr have you run into this?

Yeah, this is due to the lack of namespace separation between libmesh and moose. Specifically, this can come from 2 issues:

You are trying to compile a libtorch-related file with unity build option. You can just put that file into another folder of its own (let's say predictors/libtorch) and it will be okay. See the stochastic tools module / framework for example. Or just disable unit build (MOOSE_UNITY=false make -j50), but that makes the compilation really slow.
You have the wrong order of include files. You have to include the libtorch header files first.

Make sure that both of these are respected and you should be good. At some point I will sit down with a beverage and separate the namespaces for good,

Peter,
Thanks for the advice!
I have tried both methods, and I have some questions as it is not working yet.
First, I swapped:
#include "LibtorchArtificialNeuralNet.h"
#include <torch/torch.h>
to
#include <torch/torch.h>
#include "LibtorchArtificialNeuralNet.h"
in the header file, and that alone did not work (same error). Was there another include I should have swapped? I am also only using the "LibtorchArtificialNeuralNet.h" file as it already has some of the includes I wanted, but I don't need it for any of its body code at the moment. Would having it or getting rid of it make a difference? I tried removing the include, but it made no difference.
I then created that new folder, but wanted to know if I did it right. The predictor was originally in:
"/projects/moose/framework/predictors" and then I added another folder in that predictors folder, such that the file was now under "/projects/moose/framework/predictors/libtorch", but this gave the same error. Was this what you meant? Or was there another way I should do this?
I am trying the "MOOSE_UNITY=false make -j 1" now, but I only have 1 core, so it may take a minute (doing this on my laptop).
Thanks!
Charlie
Tried it with  "MOOSE_UNITY=false make -j 1", and once it got to my file, same error.
LibtorchArtificialNeuralNet already includes torch.h, could you try deleting torch/torch.h? Or use #pragma once on the very top?

I tried both - same error. It seems odd that LibtorchArtificialNeuralNet will compile, but my script that includes it will not. Both with and without #pragma once.
I also tried removing the "#ifdef LIBTORCH_ENABLED" to see if that was causing anything, but same error.

This will be a stupid question and no offence since I have been in this situation many times. Are you sure you are compiling with your modifications? Sometimes you might work in a different directory/moose where you are compiling. So you might be trying to compile the unmodified file. At this point this is the only reason I can think of. You can try to post your header here, maybe we can find a few other issues.

Haha, absolutely none taken, done that before. I just removed the libtorch references from the header and it compiled fine (as it did before I added the libtorch references), so I am compiling with modifications.
I have attached my file below (let me know if it didn't attach properly) as a txt file (github didn't accept the .i file) with all the libtorch parts commented out. The issue may be on a totally different section, I'm not sure. Let me know if you see anything else wrong!
MalamuteTestPredictor.txt
And, just for reference, this file lives on my computer under the directory: "~/projects/moose/framework/predictors/libtorch/MalamuteTestPredictor.i"
Is the error the same when you did the non-unity build? If not, it will be helpful if you can share the compile error with the non-unity build.

And, just for reference, this file lives on my computer under the directory: "~/projects/moose/framework/predictors/libtorch/MalamuteTestPredictor.i"

Is the suffix .i or .h?

I exited the terminal between now and when I ran without unity, but I am pretty sure it was about the same. Once again the "reference to 'Tensor' is ambiguous" error followed by a list of other errors.
I think it was about the same, but if small differences between the errors would make a large difference, I can try running that again and sending both errors with and without!
.h, my bad - I was typing from memory, not copying
Oh, so the order of predictor includes and libtorch includes makes a difference? I misunderstood your earlier message, sorry about that! I'll try this one out - thank you!
Yeah this is the result of not separating MOOSE and libMesh namespaces. I might try to have a stab at it during the winter break, might recruit others too.

I see - just tried it and it compiled!
Thank you so much for the help!

node.title: Peacock won't run. It says aborted about 2 minutes after I run it.
node.bodyText:
I installed moose pretty recently and for visualization would like to use peacock as that's what the rest of the team is using.
I set things up, added the path in .bashrc, set up xlaunch, initiated Xlaunch before opening the terminal and when I navigate to the exmaples directory in moose and run moose for the example I built it returns a simple "Aborted" message and no more information.
Would appreciated any sort of help. Thanks a bunch!

Please do not post images of text. Using images prevents any sort of search for the text contained within the image.
Are you able to display any sort of X functionality? xeyes for example?

okay I think I got it to work. I had set the IP wrong.
But now I get an error that says segmentation fault. I am trying to run the first example in the examples folder by the way. It's called ex01_inputfile.
Can you help me with this?

If you run the input file on the command line manually, does it still segfault?
cd ~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
./ex01-opt -i ex01.i

Interesting, I must not have hit "reply". I had something all typed up... but I do not see my post!
Do you mean to say that peacock launches correctly? But fails to run the problem?
Whats happens when you call peacock directly?
cd ~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
../../python/peacock/peacock -i ex01.i
Also, lets try to run a render test (tests most Peacock VTK/Qt/PyQt functionality):
export PYTHONPATH=$HOME/moose/python
cd ~/moose/python/chigger/tests/writers
./writers.py

Calling peacock through path results in the same segment fault.
Peacock launches correctly and I even see a new peacock window open that says looking for executable and then the terminal says found executable with a path to it and then suddenly it shows segmentation fault and the entire operation drops right there.
Running ./writers.py gives:
(moose) devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/python/chigger/tests/writers$ ./writers.py Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/devansh/moose/python/chigger/tests/writers/./writers.py", line 15, in <module> import chigger ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'chigger'
Do I need to manually install this library? Is this holding it back?

Based on that output you need to make sure the MOOSE Python modules are available, as @milljm mentioned in his suggestion:
export PYTHONPATH=$PYTHONPATH:$HOME/moose/python

chigger is supplied within that directory.

Hmm interesting. I think Peacock at that moment (when its up and now searching for an executable) will have something to do with Peacock finding the executable, and something going wrong when the executable is run with the json dump args.
Can you perform the following, and report back if it completes, or dies (it will print a lot of information to the screen)?
cd ~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
./ex01-opt --json
This does complete. Ends with End JSON Data

If you run the input file on the command line manually, does it still segfault?
cd ~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
./ex01-opt -i ex01.i


No it works manually. Gives me a "solve converged" message.
No luck with peacock though.

I am at home using my WSL machine, and can confirm the abort message...
I have a temporary workaround, but it requires you to maintain two Conda environments. Can you try the following:
mamba deactivate
mamba create -n peacock moose-peacock=2022.12.05
mamba activate peacock
<try to launch peacock as you have been doing>
The issue, will be that when you want to build MOOSE or MOOSE examples, etc, you will need to operate in the 'moose' environment. You can have as many activate environments as you want, so long as you run them from different terminal windows.
I have created an issue to remedy this in a future moose-dev update: #25598

Thanks a lot man! This community is super helpful.
Ran into another issue though which I can't seem to figure out. Running peacock the output says it lacks some kind of authorization and aborts. I made sure to launch vcxsrv before launching the terminal and rebuilt it using make. Am I doing something wrong? Does this work on your machine?
(peacock) devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile$ peacock
Authorization required, but no authorization protocol specified
Aborted
(peacock) devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile$

I was getting that... I needed to hit the little check box when launching VcXsrv, to... Oh I forget the terminology, something about access control. Its the last checkbox. I had to check it... Then restart Ubuntu WSL, then it started to work.
EDIT: I know I posted a bunch of screen shots about how I got it all working a year or so ago... I'll link the discussion when I find it!
Found it: #22718 (reply in thread)
You have to "Disable Access Control"

Super sorry I know I am bothering you too much at this point but the authorization issue has  been resolved and I just ran into a segmentation error:
base) devansh@HP_15s:~$ conda activate peacock
(peacock) devansh@HP_15s:~$ cd moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
(peacock) devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile$ peacock
QStandardPaths: XDG_RUNTIME_DIR not set, defaulting to '/tmp/runtime-devansh'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 180, 180, 180, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 180, 180, 180, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
Found executable: /home/devansh/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile/ex01-opt
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 180, 180, 180, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 180, 180, 180, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
Segmentation fault
(peacock) devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile$ 

Really appreciate your help!

I wonder if you issue is the same as the last message posted on the link I mentioned (about a segfault).
Can you delete ex01-opt, and re-run peacock? Just to see if it pops up?
conda activate peacock
cd moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
rm ex01-opt
peacock
Rebuilding the example is quick as all it needs to do is relink:
conda activate moose
cd moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
make

I wonder if installing this package may help:
sudo apt-get install x11-apps libglu1-mesa libgl1-mesa-glx
                                           ^^^^^^^^^ not a part of our instructions
                                                     but I performed this on my machine

Okay interesting. When the ex01-opt file is present it doesn't pop up and gives segmentation fault but when I delete it it does pop up but obviously nothing to display. I ran make again and tried running peacock again only to run into the segmentation fault again.

It's acting as though it cannot parse the dump (ex01-opt --dump) that Peacock needs to parse. I know you've tried this once before, but what happens you attempt to do that while using the Peacock environment?
conda activate peacock
cd moose/examples/ex01_inputfile
./ex01-opt --dump
Edit:
actually I believe its --json that Peacock is using:
./ex01-opt --json

Looks like it's printing a huge json file.
Dump also returns loads of text but in another format I reckon.

node.title: A thrown is thrown when I update and rebuild petsc by running update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh scripts.
node.bodyText:
Holle

The error message in the terminal window is as follows.

 **Installing Mumps; this may take several minutes                           ================================================================================TESTING: check from config.libraries(config/BuildSystem/config/libraries.py:157)*******************************************************************************
         UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Downloaded mumps could not be used. Please check install in /home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose
*******************************************************************************

There was an error. Exiting...**         

2. The error message in the log is as follows.

TESTING: check from config.libraries(config/BuildSystem/config/libraries.py:157)
  Checks that the library "libName" contains "funcs", and if it does defines HAVE_LIB"libName"
       - libDir may be a list of directories
       - libName may be a list of library names
                Checking for functions [dmumps_c] in library ['/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libcmumps.a', 'libdmumps.a', 'libsmumps.a', 'libzmumps.a', 'libmumps_common.a', 'libpord.a', 'libmpiseq.a'] ['/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libptesmumps.a', 'libptscotchparmetis.a', 'libptscotch.a', 'libptscotcherr.a', 'libesmumps.a', 'libscotch.a', 'libscotcherr.a', '/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libparmetis.a', '/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libmetis.a', '/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libscalapack.a', '/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libflapack.a', '/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib/libfblas.a', 'libm.a', '-lstdc++', '-ldl', '-lmpichfort', '-lmpich', '-lgfortran', '-lm', '-Wl,-rpath,/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/11', '-L/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/11', '-lgfortran', '-lm', '-lgcc_s', '-lquadmath']
                Checking directory of requested libraries:/home/zhao/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/arch-moose/lib for first library:libcmumps.
                Files in directory:['libsuperlu_dist.so', 'libsuperlu_dist_fortran.so.7', 'libstrumpack.so', 'libhdf5.so.200.1.0', 'libmetis.so', 'libptscotcherrexit.a', 'libscalapack.a', 'libsmumps.a', 'libptscotcherr.a', 'pkgconfig', 'libsuperlu_dist.a', 'libmumps_common.a', 'libhdf5.settings', 'libptscotchparmetis.a', 'libfblas.a', 'libsuperlu_dist.so.7', 'libscotch.a', 'libscotcherrexit.a', 'libzmumps.a', 'libhdf5_hl.la', 'libhdf5.la', 'libhdf5_hl.so', 'libptscotch.a', 'libscotchmetis.a', 'libscotcherr.a', 'libesmumps.a', 'libpord.a', 'libflapack.a', 'libhdf5_hl.a', 'libsuperlu_dist_fortran.so.7.1.1', 'libhdf5_hl.so.200', 'libcmumps.a', 'libhdf5.a', 'libhdf5.so', 'libptesmumps.a', 'petsc', 'libhdf5_hl.so.200.0.1', 'libsuperlu_dist_fortran.so', 'libhdf5.so.200', 'libdmumps.a', 'libsuperlu_dist.so.7.1.1', 'libparmetis.so']
===== Checking linker
Executing: mpicc -c -o /tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.libraries/conftest.o -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.compilerFlags -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.utilities.closure -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.compilersFortran -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.headers -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.utilities.cacheDetails -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.types -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.functions -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.utilities.featureTestMacros -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.utilities.missing -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/PETSc.options.sharedLibraries -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/PETSc.options.scalarTypes -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.packages.MPI -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.packages.metis -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.packages.pthread -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.packages.BlasLapack -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.packages.SuperLU_DIST -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.setCompilers -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.libraries -I/tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.compilers  -fPIC -Wall -Wwrite-strings -Wno-strict-aliasing -Wno-unknown-pragmas -Wno-misleading-indentation -Wno-stringop-overflow -fstack-protector -fvisibility=hidden -g -O -fopenmp   /tmp/petsc-7dwuntdm/config.libraries/conftest.c 
Successful compile:
Source:
#include "confdefs.h"
#include "conffix.h"
/* Override any gcc2 internal prototype to avoid an error. */
char dmumps_c();
static void _check_dmumps_c() { dmumps_c(); }

int main() {
_check_dmumps_c();;
  return 0;
}

This looks like you ran the diagnostic script while not in the moose environment.
The questions asked below from @cticenhour are still valid, and we need to know. Are you attempting to use our Conda packages (moose-dev) or are you wanting to build using your own compiler stack?

Are you using the MOOSE conda packages? If so, when you run the petsc script, try doing the following:
scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh FFLAGS=$FFLAGS

If you are not using the conda package, the point of this is to give MUMPS a better idea of where your MPI library is located. In a scenario without conda, we'd need more information. Could you also give me the output of
mpicc -show

With strange MPI related errors, I've also needed to build PETSc using the following switch in the past:
scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --LIBS=-lmpicxx

node.title: Math invalid error in calculation
node.bodyText:

I am developing new crystal plasticity code based on CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
I encounter a error in gdb mode
I don't what's going in my code, and how to fix it
Thanks

node.title: Request for Access to Source Code or MOOSE/MARMOT Permissions for CP-PF coupled model
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Community,
I am a researcher interested in the topic of grain boundary migration and its connection to plasticity deformation. I have recently come across the paper titled "On the plastic driving force of grain boundary migration: A fully coupled phase field and crystal plasticity model," which has sparked my interest in further developing a grain boundary migration model that incorporates fatigue loading.
I am reaching out to inquire if it would be possible to access the relevant source code or obtain the permission for using MOOSE/MARMOT, as mentioned in the aforementioned paper. The insights and techniques discussed in the paper have provided valuable inspiration for my research, and I believe that access to the code or MOOSE/MARMOT would significantly facilitate model development in this part.
I understand the importance of respecting intellectual property and licensing agreements, and I am fully committed to adhering to any terms and conditions associated with the use of the code or software. My research aims to contribute to the understanding of grain boundary migration under fatigue loading, and I believe that MOOSE/MARMOT would be an invaluable tool in achieving this goal.
If it is possible to provide access or guidance on how to obtain the code or permissions for using MOOSE/MARMOT, I would greatly appreciate your assistance. Please let me know if there are any specific procedures or requirements for obtaining access.
Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to any guidance or support you can provide, and I am excited about the potential for further advancements in the field of grain boundary migration.
Sincerely,
Wei Peng

Hello
Access to all closed source MOOSE-apps developed by INL can be requested here:
https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/Login
Do you have any collaborators in the US national labs?
While we cannot guarantee a timeline, we are working to open-source MARMOT. Most of MARMOT relies on the MOOSE phase field module which is open-source.
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you for your prompt response and for providing the link for requesting access to closed source MARMOT developed by INL.
Regarding your question about collaborators in the US national labs, I must regretfully inform you that I do not currently have any collaborators at US national labs. However, I remain open to potential collaborations in the future, as I believe we could be mutually beneficial.
I also understand that obtaining access to MARMOT may have specific requirements, including affiliation with a US-based institution. I have encountered this limitation while attempting to fill out the access request form. At present, my affiliation is not with a US-based institution, which unfortunately restricts my ability to request access.
Furthermore, I would like to clarify that my current research needs do not require access to the complete MARMOT codebase. Based on the content of the aforementioned paper, I believe that access to the relevant source code mentioned in the paper would suffice for my research purposes. If it is possible for the MOOSE developers to share the specific code related to the concepts discussed in the paper, it would greatly assist me in my research efforts.
I truly appreciate your consideration and assistance in this matter. Access to the specific source code referenced in the paper would be immensely valuable for advancing my research on grain boundary migration and fatigue loading.
Thank you once again for your help, and I look forward to any further guidance or support you can provide.
Best regards,
wei

I'll let Marmot developers comment on whether there's anything else we can do outside of the normal processes.
@laagesen  @dschwen

Hello @GiudGiud,
I wanted to follow up on our previous discussion regarding access to the MARMOT source code. In your previous response, you mentioned that you would let the MARMOT developers comment on whether there's anything else that can be done outside of the normal processes.
I would appreciate any further information or updates on this matter. Your assistance in facilitating access to the relevant source code, as mentioned in the paper, would significantly aid my research efforts.
Thank you for your attention to this request, and I look forward to hearing from you or the MARMOT developers.
Best regards,
Wei Peng

Hello
Nothing more I can do on my end unfortunately.
Guillaume

I don’t think there is any capability in marmot that is not in the phase field module. The only thing that might be missing is information related to nuclear materials but you have only spoken thus far about general modeling capability so it seems like you should just move forward why the phase field module.

Hello @lindsayad ,
In response to your comment, I would like to clarify that the MOOSE phase field module currently lacks specific examples and code implementations of the crystal plasticity-phase field coupling model discussed in Zhao L's paper. The paper clearly states that this coupled model is included in the MOOSE/MARMOT simulation package.
Also, it's worth noting that elastic energy driven grain growth can indeed be found under the path combined\examples\phase_field-mechanics\, so I think MARMOT's "Combined" module should contain a similar simulation example. This simulation example uses a crystal plasticity-phase field coupling model.
Thanks for your time and help.
Sincerely,
wei
@PengWei97 you should contact the corresponding author of that paper and confirm that MARMOT is necessary, i.e. MARMOT has capabilities that MOOSE doesn't have.
Marmot doesn’t have a combined module
But it does look like there are some good examples
Hi @hugary1995, thank you very much for your suggestion. I will send an inquiry email to the corresponding author for verification.

Hello @GiudGiud @laagesen @dschwen,
I understand that providing direct access to the MARMOT code may be challenging, considering its current closed-source status. I appreciate the challenges involved in sharing the entire codebase.
As GiudGiud suggested, I'm looking forward to help and answers from MARMOT experts and the community on specific aspects of my research. In the context of a unified description of crystal plasticity and phase field coupled model, specifically discussed in the zhao_CMS2017 paper, my main focus is on the calculation of variables and initial state variables  corresponding to activated grains (gr_i) at each integration point.
To elaborate, I perceive two types of non-uniformities in this context: one related to variations between grains, and another associated with variations within individual grains. Handling the former, where different grains interact, appears straightforward by utilizing the weighted averaging method as outlined in the paper.
However, it is the latter aspect, internal variations within a grain, that I seek clarification on. My understanding is that in a crystal plasticity model, at each integration point, there exist unique and well-defined "variables and initial state variables." Yet, the paper mentions the calculation of "initial state variables" for each activated grain gr_i at each integration point, which I find somewhat unclear.
Therefore, I kindly request guidance and insights on addressing this second type of non-uniformity, particularly the calculation of "initial state variables" for each activated grain at individual integration points within a crystal plasticity model. Any assistance, explanation, or references that could shed light on this matter would be greatly appreciated.
I am eager to deepen my understanding of this concept, and your valuable input will contribute significantly to the advancement of my research. Thank you for your time, and I look forward to hearing from the experts and the community on this forum.
Best regards,
Wei peng

node.title: Retrieving std::vector<Real> material property as an auxvariable.
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Is there a way to retrieve a declared std::vector<Real> material property as an auxvariable? Currently, it is possible for only Real material properties. Thx.
You can do it component by component using the MaterialStdVectorAux I think

See this documentation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/MaterialStdVectorAux.html

node.title: No module named 'packaging'
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I've been trying to install get moose to work on my M1 Macbook Air, but during the build of moose, I get this error:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/Alireza/projects/moose/framework/scripts/get_repo_revision.py", line 19, in <module>
    from packaging import version
**ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'packaging'**
Checking if header needs updating: /Users/Alireza/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...

Failed to generate MooseRevision.h

make: *** [/Users/Alireza/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:351: /Users/Alireza/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h] Error 1
(moose) Alirezas-MacBook-Air:test Alireza$ 

Reinstalling packaging also did not seem to be helpful on this matter, any suggestions from you guys is appreciated. Thanks!

hello
The problem is likely that the python found during the make process is not the one you installed packaging for.
You can either:

install packaging on the system python
OR
check the PATH environment variable to see why the wrong python is being found before the mamba python

Guillaume
